question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
Bankrupts are those who are i̲n̲c̲a̲p̲a̲b̲l̲e̲ to pay their debts.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 18-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct Answer: Incompetent

Explanation:
The correct word to replace "incapable" in the sentence is "incompetent", which means lacking the ability or skill to do something effectively. In this context, it refers to individuals who are unable to pay their debts.

Other Options:

  • "Powerful" –it means having great strength or influence, which is unrelated.

  • "Meagre" –it means small or insufficient in quantity, which does not fit the context.

  • "Capable" –it means having the ability to do something, which is opposite to the intended meaning.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Aesthetic value is specifically a way in which we c̲a̲n̲ ̲g̲e̲t̲ ̲p̲o̲s̲i̲t̲i̲v̲e̲ ̲c̲o̲n̲c̲l̲u̲d̲e̲ ̲v̲a̲l̲u̲e̲ from the world at large.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 23-Sep Shift 2)
option_1: can get positive convulsive value
option_2: can get positive convalescent value
option_3: can get positive contrastive value
option_4: can get positive conclusive value
solution:
Correct Answer: can get positive conclusive value
Explanation: The word "conclusive" fits logically here, as it refers to something that provides clear, decisive, and final value, which matches the context of "aesthetic value."
Other options:

  • can get positive convulsive value: "Convulsive" refers to something related to spasms or violent movements, which does not fit the context.

  • can get positive convalescent value: "Convalescent" refers to recovery after illness, which is unrelated to the context.

  • can get positive contrastive value: "Contrastive" refers to differences or comparisons, which does not make sense in this context.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Do you know w̲h̲e̲r̲e̲ ̲d̲o̲e̲s̲ ̲s̲h̲e̲ ̲r̲e̲s̲i̲d̲e̲ ?

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 18-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer: where she resides?

Explanation:
In indirect questions, the sentence structure does not follow the usual question format (i.e., no auxiliary verb before the subject). Instead, it follows the structure of a statement:

  • Direct question: "Where does she reside?"

  • Indirect question: "Do you know where she resides?"

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The c̲y̲n̲i̲c̲a̲l̲ investors believed in every word the analysts said.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 23-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer: Credulous
Explanation: "Credulous" refers to someone who is too willing to believe things, often without questioning them. This is the correct substitution for "cynical," which in this context means someone who is skeptical or doubting.
Other options:

  • Persuasive: Refers to someone who is able to convince others, which doesn't fit the context of the investors' belief.

  • Distrustful: Refers to a person who has no trust or confidence, which is the opposite of "credulous."

  • Credible: Refers to something or someone that is believable, but it doesn’t fit the context of the investors themselves.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Athens was suffering under the rule of a̲ ̲p̲o̲w̲e̲r̲f̲u̲l̲ ̲s̲m̲a̲l̲l̲ ̲g̲r̲o̲u̲p̲ that had no concern for the people's welfare.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 23-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer: an oligarchy
Explanation: "Oligarchy" refers to a small group of people who hold power, which fits the description of a small, powerful group that rules without concern for the welfare of the people.
Other options:

  • A monarchy: Refers to rule by a king or queen, which doesn’t match the description of a small group.

  • A democracy: Refers to a system of government where people have the power to vote and make decisions, which is the opposite of the situation described.

  • A missionary: Refers to a person sent on a religious mission, which doesn’t relate to governance or rule.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
Mayra has the a̲b̲i̲l̲i̲t̲y̲ for mathematics.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 10-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer: aptitude
Explanation:

  • Aptitude refers to a natural talent or ability for something, in this case, mathematics.

  • Astute means having or showing an ability to notice and understand things clearly; it does not fit the context here.

  • Altitude refers to the height of an object or point in relation to sea level or ground level.

  • Attitude refers to a settled way of thinking or feeling about something, but does not refer to natural ability.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined part of the following sentence.
The playwright has faced m̲a̲n̲y̲ ̲u̲p̲s̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲d̲o̲w̲n̲s̲ in his literary career, which spanned for almost 30 years.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 26-Sep Shift 3)
option_3: many good and bad times
solution:
Correct Answer:many good and bad times

Explanation: The phrase "ups and downs" refers to the fluctuations or varying experiences of success and failure in life or career. The most appropriate substitution is "many good and bad times," as it conveys the same meaning.

Other options:

  • many agreements and disagreements: Refers to differing opinions rather than life’s fluctuations.

  • much light and darkness: A metaphorical phrase, but not a direct substitute for "ups and downs."

  • much truth and falsehood: Refers to honesty versus dishonesty, not the changes in fortune over time.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
‘Spy Family’ is a graphic novel that is a narrative work in which the story is conveyed to the reader using u̲n̲i̲n̲t̲e̲r̲r̲u̲p̲t̲e̲d̲ ̲a̲r̲t̲ ̲i̲n̲ ̲a̲ ̲t̲r̲a̲d̲i̲t̲i̲o̲n̲a̲l̲ comics format.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 09-Sep Shift 1)
option_1: longitudinal art in a traditional
option_2: existential art in a traditional
option_3: sequential art in a traditional
option_4: sedimental art in a traditional
solution:
Correct Answer: sequential art in a traditional

Explanation: The term "sequential art" specifically refers to the format of comics and graphic novels, where the story is conveyed through a sequence of images. This aligns perfectly with the context of the sentence.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution’.

solution:
Correct answer: - hard you work

Explanation: -

  • The correct word order for this sentence should be "No matter how hard you work," which is grammatically correct.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution’.
Satya is always g̲r̲e̲a̲t̲ to his friends who helped him when he was in trouble.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 13-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer: - grateful

Explanation:
The correct word is "grateful", which means feeling or showing thanks for something. The word "great" in the sentence is incorrect as it refers to something large or excellent, not showing appreciation.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
I saw a shabby looking man living in the c̲a̲v̲i̲t̲y̲ of a mountain.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 24-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer:hole

Explanation: The word "cavity" refers to a hollow space or hole in something. In this context, the best substitution is "hole", as it correctly conveys the meaning of a hollow space in a mountain.

Other options:

  • "Height" –it refers to how tall something is.

  • "Elevation" –it refers to the height of a place above sea level.

  • "Mound" –it refers to a raised mass of earth or rocks, not a hollow space.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
V̲e̲r̲i̲t̲y̲ is a good virtue for human life.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 26-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct Answer: Truth
Explanation: The word "verity" refers to the quality of being true or truthful. Therefore, "truth" is the most appropriate substitute.
Other options:

  • Cooperation: Refers to the act of working together, which is not related to truthfulness.

  • Information: Refers to knowledge or data, which is not the same as truth.

  • Knowledge: Refers to awareness or understanding, which is different from the concept of truth.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined part in the following sentence.
Everyone called the reporter a̲ ̲d̲a̲r̲e̲d̲e̲v̲i̲l̲ after he came back safely from the war zone.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 13-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct answer: - "a fearless person."

Explanation: The term "daredevil" refers to someone who takes risks or does things that are daring, often without fear. Therefore, "a fearless person" is the correct synonym in this context.

Correct sentence: Everyone called the reporter a fearless person after he came back safely from the war zone.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
Spreading awareness about the rights of the consumers and the relief open to them in case they d̲i̲d̲ ̲n̲o̲t̲ ̲g̲e̲t̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲i̲r̲ ̲m̲o̲n̲e̲y̲’̲s̲ ̲w̲o̲r̲t̲h̲ of goods and service has rightly been identified as the first priority.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 09-Sep Shift 2)
option_2: did not getting their money’s worth
option_3: were unable to get their money’s worth

solution:
Correct Answer:were unable to get their money’s worth

Explanation: The phrase "were unable to get their money’s worth" is the correct choice because it conveys that consumers could not receive the value of their money, which fits the context of the sentence.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Nina has not yet learned how to s̲t̲r̲a̲i̲g̲h̲t̲e̲n̲ ̲u̲p̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲f̲l̲y̲ ̲r̲i̲g̲h̲t̲.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 24-Sep Shift 2)
option_1: improve her absurd behaviour and act seriously
option_2: remember the past and prepare for the future
option_3: forget the wrongdoings of the others

solution:

The idiom "straighten up and fly right" means to start behaving properly, act responsibly, or improve one's conduct. Therefore, the best substitution for the underlined segment is "improve her absurd behaviour and act seriously."

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Positive self-talk h̲a̲v̲e̲ ̲a̲ ̲g̲r̲e̲a̲t̲ ̲a̲f̲f̲e̲c̲t̲ on one’s self-worth.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 24-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct Answer:has a great effect

Explanation:
The subject "Positive self-talk" is singular, so the verb should be "has" instead of "have." Additionally, the correct noun here is "effect" (which means "a result or impact"), not "affect" (which is usually a verb meaning "to influence").

Correct sentence:
"Positive self-talk has a great effect on one’s self-worth."

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Experts acknowledged that some c̲o̲u̲n̲t̲e̲r̲f̲e̲i̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲d̲o̲c̲u̲m̲e̲n̲t̲ techniques are virtually impossible to detect.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 17-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct answer: forgery

Explanation: "Counterfeiting" refers to the act of producing fake versions of something, typically documents, money, or goods, with the intent to deceive. The most suitable synonym for "counterfeiting" in the given context is "forgery", which specifically refers to the act of making a fake document or signature with fraudulent intent.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
Our legal system must frame proper legal rules for j̲u̲v̲e̲n̲i̲l̲e̲ criminals.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 11-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
The correct answer is: young

Explanation:

The word "juvenile" refers to something related to young people, especially in the context of crime or law, where it refers to minors or young offenders.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
There are many factories in the o̲p̲e̲r̲a̲t̲i̲v̲e̲ area of the city.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 09-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer: industrial

Explanation:
The term "industrial" refers to areas or zones related to factories and industry, which fits the context of the sentence.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
An i̲n̲t̲e̲n̲s̲e̲ wish to learn something keeps the nerves active.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 18-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer: powerful

Explanation:
The word "intense" means strong, extreme, or powerful in degree. The best substitute is "powerful", as it conveys a similar meaning of strong desire.

Other Options:

  • fixed – "fixed" means unchanging or firmly set, which does not match the meaning of "intense."

  • half-hearted – "half-hearted" means lacking enthusiasm or interest, which is the opposite of "intense."

  • lazy – "lazy" means unwilling to work or lacking energy, which is unrelated to "intense."

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The ship launched out on a j̲o̲u̲r̲n̲e̲y̲ ̲b̲y̲ ̲w̲a̲t̲e̲r̲ ̲o̲r̲ ̲s̲e̲a̲ of discovery.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 25-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct Answer:voyage

Explanation: The phrase "journey by water or sea" refers to travel over a large body of water, which is best described by the word "voyage."

Other options:

  • "verso" – Refers to the left-hand page of an open book, unrelated to the sentence.

  • "vespers" – Refers to evening prayers in some Christian traditions, not related to travel.

  • "rendezvous" – Means a meeting at an agreed time and place, which does not fit the context.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined part of the following sentence.
My brother always received t̲h̲e̲ ̲l̲i̲o̲n̲’̲s̲ ̲s̲h̲a̲r̲e̲ of every meal that we had.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 25-Sep Shift 2)
solution:
Correct Answer: the major portion

Explanation: The phrase "lion’s share" refers to the largest or most significant portion of something. In the given sentence, it means that the brother always received the biggest portion of the meal.

Other options:

  • The last bite: This refers to the final portion of food, which is usually small and does not convey the same meaning as "lion’s share."

  • The pet’s share: This suggests a portion given to a pet, which is usually smaller or less significant.

  • A very small part: This is the opposite of "lion’s share," which means the largest portion.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined word segment in the given sentence.
Sanat has just arrived in Mysore on transfer; he requests his friend Raghu to help him find a̲n̲ ̲a̲p̲p̲r̲o̲p̲r̲i̲a̲t̲e̲ ̲l̲o̲c̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 23-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Solution:
The phrase "an appropriate location" is contextually about where Sanat can stay after arriving in Mysore.

Option (a) “a suitable elevation” is incorrect – elevation refers to height above sea level, which is not relevant.

Option (b) “an allocation recommendation” is awkward and not idiomatic in this context.

Option (c) “a rented accommodation” is correct – this refers to a place to live, which fits perfectly.

Option (d) “a proper junction” refers to a road intersection – not relevant to finding a place to stay.

Answer: c) a rented accommodation

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined word segment in the given sentence.
I picked up my little clock and it began to d̲a̲n̲c̲e̲ ̲g̲r̲a̲c̲e̲f̲u̲l̲l̲y̲.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 25-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer:chime prettily

Explanation: The sentence describes a little clock that reacts when picked up. Clocks do not "dance gracefully," but they can produce sounds. "Chime prettily" is the best replacement, as it conveys the idea of a clock making a pleasant sound.

Other options:

  • "Work agreeably" – Incorrect, as clocks do not "work agreeably"; this phrase is unnatural.

  • "Lift smoothly" – Incorrect, as it describes an action of lifting rather than the clock’s reaction.

  • "Move gradually" – Incorrect, as clocks do not typically move in this way when picked up.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The b̲e̲t̲r̲a̲y̲e̲r̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲c̲o̲u̲n̲t̲r̲y̲ was at last unmasked.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 25-Sep Shift 3)
solution:
Correct Answer:traitor

Explanation: A "traitor" is someone who betrays their country, making it the most appropriate replacement for "betrayer of the country."

Other options:

  • Theist: A person who believes in God, unrelated to betrayal.

  • Truant: A person who is absent without permission, typically from school or duty.

  • Transgressor: Someone who violates a rule or law, but it does not specifically mean a betrayer of the country.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
She faced a s̲e̲s̲s̲i̲o̲n̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲a̲b̲u̲s̲e̲ after insisting that she was too beautiful to be liked.

(SSC Selection Post P-12 GL : 21 June Shift-3 GL)
solution:
Let's break down the options and why "tirade of abuse" is the best choice:

  • Recital of abuse:

  • "Recital" generally refers to a formal or public performance, often in a structured or poetic manner. It doesn’t convey the intensity or negativity associated with the context of "abuse." It would be awkward in this context because abuse isn't typically something recited in a formal or planned way.

  • Tirade of abuse:

  • A "tirade" is a long, angry, or violent speech. It conveys the idea of a sustained and intense verbal attack. In this context, it makes sense because it describes an ongoing or forceful verbal assault (abuse), which aligns with the sentence's tone.

  • Recitation of abuse:

  • Similar to "recital," "recitation" refers to the act of repeating something from memory, often in a formal way. This option is less appropriate because it implies a more structured, perhaps even neutral, repetition of words, which doesn't fit the emotional weight of the sentence.

  • Declamation of abuse:

  • "Declamation" refers to a formal, often rhetorical speech, usually with a strong oratory style. It is not commonly used to describe verbal abuse. This term would not accurately capture the raw, angry nature of abuse in the context of the sentence.

Thus, "tirade of abuse" is the best choice because it conveys the idea of a harsh, continuous verbal attack, fitting the context of the sentence where someone faces verbal mistreatment after a bold claim.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment.
Ruby fell victim to the g̲r̲e̲e̲n̲ ̲e̲y̲e̲d̲ ̲m̲o̲n̲s̲t̲e̲r̲.

(SSC Selection Post P-12 HSL : 21 June Shift-2 HSL)
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment "green-eyed monster" is:

jealousy

Explanation:

  • "Green-eyed monster" is an idiom that refers to jealousy. The phrase was popularized by Shakespeare in Othello, where it symbolizes the destructive nature of jealousy.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Stop b̲e̲a̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲a̲r̲o̲u̲n̲d̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲b̲u̲s̲h̲ and tell me what is expected out of me.

(SSC Selection Post P-12 ML : 24 June Shift-4 ML)
option_3: revealing a secret to everyone
option_4: avoiding to talk about the issue
solution:
The correct answer is "avoiding to talk about the issue."

The idiom "beating around the bush" means avoiding a direct answer or avoiding talking about something directly. In this context, the sentence is asking someone to stop avoiding the issue and be clear about what is expected.

The other options don't fit the meaning of the idiom:

  • Misunderstanding the situation: Doesn't relate to the idiom.

  • Getting the conversation going: Refers to initiating a conversation, not avoiding it.

  • Revealing a secret to everyone: Not related to avoiding or circling around a topic.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
You have hurt so many people. Now, it is time t̲o̲ ̲g̲e̲t̲ ̲a̲ ̲t̲a̲s̲t̲e̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲y̲o̲u̲r̲ ̲o̲w̲n̲ ̲m̲e̲d̲i̲c̲i̲n̲e̲.̲

(SSC Selection Post P-12 ML : 21 June Shift-4 ML)
option_1: to lose control in a situation
option_2: to benefit from two different opportunities
option_3: to be in a risky situation
option_4: to be treated the way you have treated others
solution:
The correct option that can substitute the underlined segment "to get a taste of your own medicine" is:

to be treated the way you have treated others

Explanation:

  • "To get a taste of your own medicine" is an idiom that means experiencing the consequences of one's own actions, especially when those actions have negatively affected others.

  • The other options do not match the meaning of the idiom:

  • To lose control in a situation: This refers to losing one's composure or control, which is not related to the idiom.

  • To benefit from two different opportunities: This has no relation to the idea of experiencing the consequences of one's actions.

  • To be in a risky situation: This also does not align with the idiom’s meaning.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
We should not u̲n̲d̲e̲r̲e̲s̲t̲i̲m̲a̲t̲e̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲s̲i̲g̲n̲i̲f̲i̲c̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲ ̲of female education.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-3)
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined words in the given sentence is:

"underestimate the significance"

Explanation:

  • The correct phrase is "underestimate the significance", where "underestimate" is followed by "the" and "significance" to correctly convey the meaning of not recognizing the full importance of something.

  • The other options are incorrect because:

  • "underestimate signification" lacks the necessary article "the" before "signification."

  • "underestimate on signification" is grammatically incorrect due to the unnecessary preposition "on."

  • "underestimate at signification" is also incorrect because "at" is the wrong preposition to use here.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Amit is also a c̲h̲i̲p̲ ̲o̲f̲f̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲o̲l̲d̲ ̲b̲l̲o̲c̲k̲ like his brother, Tandon.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-3)
option_1: getting ready for the future endeavours
option_2: resembling his parents in character and appearance
option_4: talking to others tough like a stone
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is:

Resembling his parents in character and appearance.

This is the meaning of the idiom "a chip off the old block," which refers to someone who is similar to their parent or predecessor in character, appearance, or behavior.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
He is feeding a̲ ̲m̲a̲l̲e̲ ̲d̲o̲g̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲f̲e̲m̲a̲l̲e̲ ̲d̲o̲g̲

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-3)
option_3: a dog and a bitch
option_4: a male dog and lady dog
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is:

"a dog and a bitch"

Correct sentence:

He is feeding a dog and a bitch.

Explanation:

  • The term "bitch" is the correct biological term for a female dog.

  • While the original sentence is grammatically correct, this substitution makes the sentence more concise and clear.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the highlighted words in the given sentence.
The serenity of the river was a sight to behold.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-3)
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the highlighted words is:

"pleasant to see"

Correct sentence:

The serenity of the river was pleasant to see.

Explanation:

  • The phrase "a sight to behold" means something that is very beautiful or impressive to look at, which aligns with "pleasant to see."

  • The other options do not fit the context of describing the serenity of the river.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence to make it a meaningful sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution’.
The quality of students o̲f̲ ̲a̲n̲ ̲e̲d̲u̲c̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲a̲l̲ ̲i̲n̲s̲t̲i̲t̲u̲t̲e̲ ̲i̲s̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲g̲r̲e̲a̲t̲ ̲i̲m̲p̲o̲r̲t̲a̲n̲c̲e̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲a̲ ̲c̲r̲u̲c̲i̲a̲l̲ ̲s̲t̲a̲r̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲p̲o̲i̲n̲t̲.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-3)
option_2: The quality of students in an educational institute is in great importance and a crucial starting point.
option_3: The quality of students in an educational institute is of great importance and a crucial starting point.
option_4: The quality of students in an educational institute is of great importance and is a crucial start point.
solution:
The most appropriate substitution to make the sentence meaningful is:

The quality of students in an educational institute is of great importance and a crucial starting point.

This option is grammatically correct and conveys the intended meaning clearly.

The other options are incorrect for the following reasons:

  • The quality of students in an educational institute is in great importance and a crucial starting point. ("in great importance" is not a correct phrase; it should be "of great importance.")

  • The quality of students in an educational institute is of great importance and is a crucial start point. ("start point" is awkward; "starting point" is the correct term.)

So, the correct answer is: The quality of students in an educational institute is of great importance and a crucial starting point.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
My grandmother helps us in all the problems. She has a̲ ̲r̲e̲m̲e̲d̲y̲ ̲f̲o̲r̲ ̲a̲l̲l̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲d̲i̲s̲e̲a̲s̲e̲s̲.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-3)
solution:
The most appropriate substitution for the underlined words is:

Panacea

"Panacea" refers to a solution or remedy for all problems or diseases, which fits the context of the sentence where the grandmother is described as having a remedy for all diseases.

The other options are not suitable:

  • Service refers to an act of helping or serving, which doesn’t fit in the context of a remedy for diseases.

  • Heretic refers to someone who holds beliefs contrary to established doctrine, unrelated to the context.

  • Fanatic refers to someone with extreme or obsessive views, which doesn’t match the meaning of remedy.

So, the correct answer is Panacea.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined part of the given sentence.
All the k̲i̲t̲h̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲k̲i̲n̲ of my deceased landlady were present to attend her funeral.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-3)
solution:
The most appropriate substitution for the underlined part is:

blood relatives

"Kit and kin" is an idiomatic expression that refers to one's family or relatives, typically by blood. Therefore, "blood relatives" is the correct replacement.

The other options do not fit:

  • Office colleagues refers to people you work with, not family members.

  • Secret enemies refers to adversaries, which is unrelated to family.

  • Special students refers to a specific group of students, which does not align with the meaning of "kit and kin."

So, the correct answer is blood relatives.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Though Kalpana listened to Sheetal carefully, she knew that she should t̲a̲k̲e̲ ̲i̲t̲ ̲w̲i̲t̲h̲ ̲a̲ ̲g̲r̲a̲i̲n̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲s̲a̲l̲t̲.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 27 June Shift-2)
option_1: move according to the trend
option_2: accept it as really useful and worthy
option_3: regard it as exaggerated and not completely true
option_4: be do it meticulously as taking salt
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is:

"regard it as exaggerated and not completely true."

Explanation:

The idiom "take it with a grain of salt" means to view something with skepticism or doubt, not accepting it as completely accurate or true.

Corrected Sentence:

"Though Kalpana listened to Sheetal carefully, she knew that she should regard it as exaggerated and not completely true."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The author’s writing style is characterised by its p̲o̲e̲t̲i̲c̲ ̲l̲a̲n̲g̲u̲a̲g̲e̲.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 27 June Shift-2)
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment is:
"lyrical language"

Explanation:

"Poetic language" refers to a style of writing that is artistic, expressive, and often uses imagery, rhythm, and metaphor. The term "lyrical language" closely matches this description, as it suggests a musical, emotional, and poetic quality in writing.

Corrected Sentence:

"The author’s writing style is characterised by its lyrical language."

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The manager, decided at last to b̲r̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲s̲t̲e̲n̲o̲g̲r̲a̲p̲h̲e̲r̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲b̲o̲o̲k̲ for her illegal money transactions after trying to ignore it several times.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-1)
option_1: bring her for a detailed investigation
option_2: place her in a safe supportive position
option_3: make her accountable for her conduct
option_4: take her into great confidence
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is:

make her accountable for her conduct

This option fits the context of the sentence, implying that the manager has decided to address the stenographer's illegal money transactions by holding her responsible for her actions.

question:
Select the most appropriate segment to substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
He always used to say that he was not a beggar by choice and if someone could employ him, he would l̲i̲k̲e̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲e̲a̲t̲.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-1)
solution:
The most appropriate segment to substitute the underlined words in the sentence is:

love to work

The sentence would then read:
"He always used to say that he was not a beggar by choice and if someone could employ him, he would love to work."

"Love to work" makes sense in this context, as it indicates a strong desire or enthusiasm to work if given the opportunity. The other options do not fit the context as well.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined part of the following sentence.
Mathew decided to complete the marathon to prove that he is still f̲i̲t̲ ̲a̲s̲ ̲a̲ ̲f̲i̲d̲d̲l̲e̲ in his eighties.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-1)
option_1: an owner of a fit horse
option_2: a man of great qualities
option_3: a fit and energetic person
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined part "fit as a fiddle" is:

a fit and energetic person

Explanation:

  • The idiom "fit as a fiddle" means to be in excellent physical health or condition, often used to describe someone who is energetic and physically well.

  • Among the options, "a fit and energetic person" best captures this meaning.

Thus, the sentence would be:

Mathew decided to complete the marathon to prove that he is still a fit and energetic person in his eighties.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Rajan’s caused e̲x̲t̲r̲e̲m̲e̲l̲y̲ ̲p̲a̲i̲n̲f̲u̲l̲ headaches.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-1)
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment "extremely painful" in the given sentence is "excruciating."

Explanation:

  • Excruciating means something that is extremely intense and painful, making it the best choice to convey the level of pain described in the sentence.

The other options:

  • Horrible: While it suggests something unpleasant, it does not specifically describe pain.

  • Devastating: Refers to something very damaging or destructive, but not necessarily painful.

  • Extreme: Refers to something at the farthest or highest degree, but it doesn't specifically convey pain.

Thus, the correct answer is excruciating.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The company plans t̲o̲ ̲e̲x̲p̲a̲n̲d̲ its business to the international market.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-1)
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment is "to increase."

Explanation:

  • The sentence mentions expanding its business, which typically means growing or increasing its reach, particularly to new markets.

  • Therefore, "to increase" is the correct synonym in this context, as it conveys the idea of growth, which aligns with the intention of expanding into the international market.

Thus, the correct answer is "to increase."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Ratul’s capability of being ̲a̲b̲l̲e̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲s̲p̲e̲a̲k̲ ̲t̲w̲o̲ ̲l̲a̲n̲g̲u̲a̲g̲e̲s̲ ̲is apt for this post.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-2)
solution:
The most appropriate substitution for the underlined segment "being able to speak two languages" is "bilingual".

Explanation:

  • Bilingual: Refers to a person who can speak two languages fluently, making it the perfect fit for replacing the underlined segment.

  • Lingual: While related to language, it does not specifically indicate the ability to speak two languages.

  • Bicultural: Refers to someone who identifies with two cultures, which is not the same as being able to speak two languages.

  • Bidialectical: Refers to someone who can speak two dialects of the same language, which is narrower than speaking two distinct languages.

Thus, the correct answer is bilingual.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
The road is too busy for elderly people t̲h̲a̲t̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲y̲ ̲c̲a̲n̲n̲o̲t̲ ̲c̲r̲o̲s̲s̲ ̲s̲a̲f̲e̲l̲y̲.̲

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-2)
option_1: that it is impossible for them to cross.
option_3: that it cannot be crossed properly.
option_4: that it is difficult to cross.
solution:
"to cross safely" is the best option to substitute the underlined part of the sentence.

The revised sentence would be:

"The road is too busy for elderly people to cross safely."

This option accurately conveys the idea that the road is too busy for elderly people to cross without risk or danger, maintaining the intended meaning of the original sentence.

question:
In the following question a statement has been given with highlighted text. You are required to replace the text with correct phrase given in the options.
His intriguing mastery of the English language allowed him to write eloquently.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-1)
solution:
The correct phrase to replace the highlighted text is "captivating expertise".

Explanation:

  • Intriguing mastery refers to a skill or expertise that captures attention due to its fascinating nature.

  • "Captivating" means something that grabs attention, and "expertise" refers to high-level skill or mastery.

The other options are not appropriate:

  • "Master" is too vague and doesn't match the context.

  • "Wellness known skill" is grammatically incorrect.

  • "Least known talent" contradicts the idea of mastery, as it implies something that is not well-known.

Thus, the phrase "captivating expertise" best conveys the intended meaning.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the highlighted words in the given sentence.
His interpretation of the facts was impressive.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-1)
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the highlighted words is "understanding of realities."

The sentence would read: "His understanding of realities was impressive."

This option correctly uses "understanding" (a noun) and fits the context of the sentence, which describes someone's comprehension of facts or situations.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence.
My friend v̲a̲n̲i̲s̲h̲e̲d̲ ̲w̲h̲e̲n̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲g̲o̲o̲n̲s̲ ̲c̲a̲m̲e̲ to fight with me.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 27 June Shift-3)
option_1: mobilised when the thugs arrived
option_2: condemned when the thugs arrived
option_3: attacked when the thugs arrived
option_4: disappeared when the thugs arrived
solution:
The correct option to improve the underlined part of the sentence is:

"disappeared when the thugs arrived."

Corrected sentence:
"My friend disappeared when the thugs arrived to fight with me."

Explanation:

  • "Disappeared" is a better and more formal word for "vanished" in this context.

  • "Mobilised" means to organize or prepare for action, which does not fit the context.

  • "Condemned" means to express disapproval, which does not match the situation described.

  • "Attacked" would imply that the friend fought back, which contradicts the idea of vanishing.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Last night, I failed to sleep because of some f̲a̲m̲i̲l̲i̲a̲r̲ ̲i̲s̲s̲u̲e̲s̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲t̲ ̲c̲o̲u̲l̲d̲n̲’̲t̲ ̲b̲e̲ ̲a̲v̲o̲i̲d̲e̲d̲.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 27 June Shift-3)
solution:
The correct option is:

"Inevitable."

Explanation:

The word "inevitable" means something that cannot be avoided or escaped, which fits the context of the sentence.

The other options:

  • Unthinkable: Means something that is unimaginable or unlikely.

  • Incapable: Refers to lacking the ability to do something.

  • Unsolvable: Means something that cannot be solved, which is not suitable here.

question:
Select the most suitable expression that can substitute the underlined part of the sentence without any change in meaning.
Planning to go for a movie just before the final-year examination is nothing but s̲k̲a̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲o̲n̲ ̲t̲h̲i̲n̲ ̲i̲c̲e̲.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 27 June Shift-1)
option_4: being in a risky situation
solution:
The most suitable expression that can substitute the underlined part "skating on thin ice" without changing the meaning is:

being in a risky situation

"Skating on thin ice" is an idiom that means being in a dangerous or risky situation, which fits perfectly with the idea of planning to go for a movie just before the final-year examination.

Here’s why the other options are incorrect:

  • Enjoying the moment doesn’t convey the idea of risk or danger.

  • Going to hill stations is unrelated to the idea of being in a risky situation.

  • Doing hard work also doesn't capture the essence of being in a dangerous or precarious situation.

Thus, the correct answer is being in a risky situation. The sentence would read:

"Planning to go for a movie just before the final-year examination is nothing but being in a risky situation."
